previous_headings: 2 Current menu of data models
title: Data Models
text: undercount data model assumes event person target population non-zero chance left reported total. words, inclusion probabilities less 1. user supplies prior inclusion probabilities, parameterized using means dispersions, means restricted values 0 1. precisely, undercount data model \[\begin{align}   y_i^{\text{obs}} & \sim \text{Binomial}(y_i^{\text{true}}, \pi_{g[]}) \\   \pi_g & \sim \text{Beta}\left( \frac{m_g}{d_g}, \frac{1-m_g}{d_g} \right) \end{align}\] \(y_i^{\text{obs}}\) observed value outcome variable cell \(\); \(y_i^{\text{true}}\) true value outcome variable cell \(\); \(\pi_{g[]}\) inclusion probability cell \(\) (may shared across multiple cells); \(m_g\) mean prior governing \(\pi_g\); \(d_g\) dispersion prior governing \(\pi_g\). assume, moment, cells share coverage probability, drawn distribution mean 0.8 dispersion 0.02. use function `set_datamod_undercount add ‘undercount’ data model original base model, fit new combined model Calling augment() fitted model yields usual estimates birth rate, shown .fitted .expected columns, also estimates true births, .births column: Estimated birth rates undercount model higher estimated birth rates base model, since undercount model assumes reported births understate true births.  estimates births underlying baseline undercount models: estimated coverage probability can extracted using function components():
code: prob_under <- data.frame(mean = 0.8, disp = 0.02) mod_under <- mod_base |>   set_datamod_undercount(prob = prob_under) |>   fit() mod_under #>  #>     ------ Fitted Poisson model ------ #>  #>    births ~ age #>  #>                  exposure: popn #>                data model: undercount #>  #>         term  prior along n_par n_par_free std_dev #>  (Intercept) NFix()     -     1          1       - #>          age   RW()   age     9          9    1.19 #>  #>  disp: mean = 1 #>  #>  n_draw var_age optimizer #>    1000     age    nlminb #>  #>  time_total time_max time_draw iter converged                    message #>        0.06     0.02      0.02   13      TRUE   relative convergence (4) mod_under |>   augment() #> ℹ Adding variable `.births` with true values for `births`. #> # A tibble: 9 × 7 #>   age   births           .births  popn .observed                    .fitted #>   <chr>  <int>      <rdbl<1000>> <int>     <dbl>               <rdbl<1000>> #> 1 10-14      0          0 (0, 1) 27084  0        3.4e-06 (1.3e-11, 8.5e-05) #> 2 15-19      9        11 (9, 16) 25322  0.000355   0.00044 (2e-04, 0.00081) #> 3 20-24    110    137 (120, 169) 23935  0.00460     0.0058 (0.0046, 0.0073) #> 4 25-29    912 1140 (1016, 1362) 28936  0.0315         0.039 (0.034, 0.047) #> 5 30-34   2547 3186 (2837, 3806) 30964  0.0823            0.1 (0.092, 0.12) #> 6 35-39   1235 1540 (1378, 1853) 31611  0.0391         0.049 (0.043, 0.059) #> 7 40-44    262    327 (291, 394) 44567  0.00588      0.0073 (0.0062, 0.009) #> 8 45-49      6         7 (6, 11) 41774  0.000144   0.00017 (6e-05, 0.00037) #> 9 50-54      0          0 (0, 1) 51312  0        1.5e-06 (1.3e-11, 5.3e-05) #> # ℹ 1 more variable: .expected <rdbl<1000>> mod_under |>   components() |>   filter(term == "datamod") #> # A tibble: 1 × 4 #>   term    component level         .fitted #>   <chr>   <chr>     <chr>    <rdbl<1000>> #> 1 datamod prob      prob  0.8 (0.67, 0.9)

title: Data Models
text: overcount data model assumes reported outcomes include counts people events fact come true population, double-counted. expected size overcount equals expected size true count, multiplied overcoverage rate. precisely, \[\begin{align}   y_i^{\text{obs}} & = y_i^{\text{true}} + \epsilon_i \\   \epsilon_i & \sim \text{Poisson}( \kappa_{g[]}  \gamma_i w_i) \\   \kappa_g & \sim \text{Gamma}\left(\frac{1}{d_g}, \frac{1}{m_g d_g} \right) \end{align}\] \(y_i^{\text{obs}}\) observed value outcome variable cell \(\); \(y_i^{\text{true}}\) true value outcome variable cell \(\); \(\gamma_i\) underlying rate outcome \(y_i^{\text{true}}\); \(w_i\) exposure cell \(\); \(\kappa_{g[]}\) overcoverage rate cell \(\) (may shared across multiple cells); \(m_g\) mean prior governing \(\kappa_g\); \(d_g\) dispersion prior governing \(\kappa_g\). moment, assume cells overcoverage rate, drawn distribution mean 0.1 dispersion 0.05. specify overcount model using function set_datamod_overcount(). Adding overcount data model produces birth rate estimates lower base model, since reported birth counts assumed high.
code: rate_over <- data.frame(mean = 0.1, disp = 0.05) mod_over <- mod_base |>   set_datamod_overcount(rate = rate_over)

previous_headings: 2 Current menu of data models
title: Data Models
text: miscount data model combination undercount overcount models. assumes reported outcome includes undercount, overcount. model \[\begin{align}   y_i^{\text{obs}} & = u_i + v_i \\   u_i & \sim \text{Binomial}(y_i^{\text{true}}, \pi_{g[]}) \\   v_i & \sim \text{Poisson}( \kappa_{h[]}  \gamma_i w_i) \\   \pi_g & \sim \text{Beta}\left( \frac{m_g}{d_g}, \frac{1-m_g}{d_g} \right) \\   \kappa_h & \sim \text{Gamma}\left(\frac{1}{d_h}, \frac{1}{m_h d_h} \right) \end{align}\] variables definitions undercount overcount models. need specify priors inclusion probabilities overcoverage rates. re-use priors previous models. choice priors implies undercoverage overcoverage, estimated birth rates, estimated birth counts, higher baseline model.  use components() extract estimates inclusion probability overcount rate.
code: mod_mis <- mod_base |>   set_datamod_miscount(prob = prob_under,                        rate = rate_over) mod_mis |>   components() |>   filter(term == "datamod") #> # A tibble: 2 × 4 #>   term    component level            .fitted #>   <chr>   <chr>     <chr>       <rdbl<1000>> #> 1 datamod prob      prob     0.8 (0.68, 0.9) #> 2 datamod rate      rate  0.098 (0.06, 0.15)

previous_headings: 2 Current menu of data models
title: Data Models
text: noise model assumes reported outcome equals true outcome plus noise, \[\begin{equation}   y_i^{\text{obs}} = y_i^{\text{true}} + \epsilon_i. \end{equation}\] noise assumed expected value zero. distribution depends base model noise data model applied . base model normal, noise assumed normal distribution, \[\begin{equation}   \epsilon_i \sim \text{N}(0, s_{g[]}^2) \end{equation}\] base model Poisson, noise assumed symmetric Skellam distribution, \[\begin{equation}   \epsilon_i \sim \text{Skellam}(m_{g[]}, m_{g[]}) \end{equation}\] \(m_g = \frac{1}{2} s_g^2\). Skellam distribution derived Poisson distribution. \(x_1 \sim \text{Poisson}(\mu_1)\), \(x_2 \sim \text{Poisson}(\mu_2)\), \(y = x_1 + x_2\), \(y \sim \text{Skellam}(\mu_1, \mu_2)\). two Poisson variates expected value, Skellam distribution symmetric, single parameter \(\mu\), \(\text{E}[y] = 0\) \(\text{var}[y] = 2 \mu\). Note unlike undercount, overcount, miscount data models, noise data model unknown parameters. use noise data model Poisson model, need set dispersion Poisson model 0. Function set_datamod_noise() us, good practice make change explicit: Fitting model yields following estimates. outcome variable subject known biases, measurement errors assumed mean zero. noise data model can used, outcome variable must de-biased, subtracting estimates bias.
code: mod_noise <- mod_base |>   set_disp(mean = 0) |>   set_datamod_noise(s = 50)

previous_headings: 2 Current menu of data models
title: Data Models
text: applications, exposure variable bigger measurement errors outcome variable. bage exposure data model used Poisson base models. model \[\begin{equation}   w_i^{\text{obs}} \sim \text{InvGamma}(2 + d_{g[]}^{-1}, [1 + d_{g[]}^{-1}] w_i^{\text{true}}) \end{equation}\] - \(w_i^{\text{obs}}\) observed value exposure cell \(\); - \(w_i^{\text{true}}\) true value exposure cell \(\); - \(w_i\) exposure cell \(\); - \(d_{g[]}\) dispersion parameter cell \(\) (may shared across multiple cells). model contains unknown parameters. model \[\begin{align}   E[w_i^{\text{obs}} \mid w_i^{\text{true}}] & =  w_i^{\text{true}} \\   \text{var}[w_i^{\text{obs}} \mid w_i^{\text{true}}] & = d_{g[]} ( w_i^{\text{true}})^2 \\   \text{cv}[w_i^{\text{obs}} \mid w_i^{\text{true}}] & = \sqrt{d_{g[]}} \end{align}\] ‘cv’ coefficient variation, defined standard deviation, divided mean. exposure data model specified using cv. noise data model, dispersion base model must set 0. Along estimates birth rates, model also yields estimates true population.
code: mod_expose <- mod_base |>   set_disp(mean = 0) |>   set_datamod_exposure(cv = 0.05)

title: Data Models
text: full-sized applications, generally want inclusion probabilities, coverage rates, standard deviations, coefficients variation vary across dimensions age, sex, time. data models implemented bage allow sort variation. illustrate use varying data model parameters using slightly extended version births model. use new dataset includes time variable: create new prior inclusion probabilities mean dispersion vary time: implement one model old time-constant prior, one new time-varying prior. expect, two models give different results.  Data model parameters can vary across one dimension. set prior varies across age time. Rather using different inclusion probabilities every age group, however, use one set people aged 10-34, one people aged 35+. implement , need create new, aggregated age group. model assumes births women aged 35+ 2022 subject unusual degree -reporting. results reflect assumption.
code: births_time #> # A tibble: 27 × 4 #>    age    time births  popn #>    <chr> <int>  <int> <int> #>  1 10-14  2021      0 27208 #>  2 10-14  2022      0 27185 #>  3 10-14  2023      0 27084 #>  4 15-19  2021      3 25039 #>  5 15-19  2022     16 25276 #>  6 15-19  2023      9 25322 #>  7 20-24  2021    178 29008 #>  8 20-24  2022    120 26201 #>  9 20-24  2023    110 23935 #> 10 25-29  2021   1212 30826 #> # ℹ 17 more rows prob_under_time <- data.frame(time = c(2021, 2022, 2023),                               mean = c(0.99, 0.8,  0.99),                                     disp = c(0.01, 0.02, 0.01)) mod_timeconst <- mod_pois(births ~ age + time,                           data = births_time,                                 exposure = popn) |>   set_datamod_undercount(prob = prob_under)  mod_timevarying <- mod_timeconst |>   set_datamod_undercount(prob = prob_under_time) #> → Replacing existing "undercount" data model with new "undercount" data model births_time <- births_time |>   mutate(agegp = if_else(age %in% c("10-14", "15-19",                                     "20-24", "25-29",                                     "30-34"),                          "10-34",                          "35+"))                               prob_under_agetime <- data.frame(   time =  c(2021,    2022,    2023,    2021,  2022,  2023),   agegp = c("10-34", "10-34", "10-34", "35+", "35+", "35+"),   mean =  c(0.95,    0.95,    0.95,    0.95,  0.5,  0.95),   disp =  c(0.01,    0.01,    0.01,    0.01,  0.1,  0.01))  mod_agetime <- mod_pois(births ~ age + time,                         data = births_time,                               exposure = popn) |>   set_datamod_undercount(prob = prob_under_agetime)

code: library(bage) mod <- mod_pois(injuries ~ age:sex + ethnicity + year,                 data = nzl_injuries,                 exposure = popn) |>   fit() mod #>  #>     ------ Fitted Poisson model ------ #>  #>    injuries ~ age:sex + ethnicity + year #>  #>                  exposure: popn #>  #>         term  prior along n_par n_par_free std_dev #>  (Intercept) NFix()     -     1          1       - #>    ethnicity NFix()     -     2          2    0.45 #>         year   RW()  year    19         19    0.09 #>      age:sex   RW()   age    24         24    0.88 #>  #>  disp: mean = 1 #>  #>  n_draw var_time var_age var_sexgender optimizer #>    1000     year     age           sex    nlminb #>  #>  time_total time_max time_draw iter converged                    message #>        0.52     0.08      0.09   13      TRUE   relative convergence (4) augment(mod) #> # A tibble: 912 × 9 #>    age   sex    ethnicity  year injuries  popn .observed #>    <fct> <chr>  <chr>     <int>    <int> <int>     <dbl> #>  1 0-4   Female Maori      2000       12 35830 0.000335  #>  2 5-9   Female Maori      2000        6 35120 0.000171  #>  3 10-14 Female Maori      2000        3 32830 0.0000914 #>  4 15-19 Female Maori      2000        6 27130 0.000221  #>  5 20-24 Female Maori      2000        6 24380 0.000246  #>  6 25-29 Female Maori      2000        6 24160 0.000248  #>  7 30-34 Female Maori      2000       12 22560 0.000532  #>  8 35-39 Female Maori      2000        3 22230 0.000135  #>  9 40-44 Female Maori      2000        6 18130 0.000331  #> 10 45-49 Female Maori      2000        6 13770 0.000436  #> # ℹ 902 more rows #> # ℹ 2 more variables: .fitted <rdbl<1000>>, .expected <rdbl<1000>>

title: Autoregressive Prior — AR
text: AR() used interaction, separate AR processes constructed along 'along' variable, within combination '' variables. default, autoregressive processes order 2. Alternative choices can specified n_coef argument. Argument s controls size innovations. Smaller values s tend give smoother estimates.

title: Autoregressive Prior — AR
text: AR() used main effect, $$\beta_j = \phi_1 \beta_{j-1} + \cdots + \phi_{\mathtt{n\_coef}} \beta_{j-\mathtt{n\_coef}} + \epsilon_j$$ $$\epsilon_j \sim \text{N}(0, \omega^2),$$ used interaction, $$\beta_{u,v} = \phi_1 \beta_{u,v-1} + \cdots + \phi_{\mathtt{n\_coef}} \beta_{u,v-\mathtt{n\_coef}} + \epsilon_{u,v}$$ $$\epsilon_{u,v} \sim \text{N}(0, \omega^2),$$ \(\pmb{\beta}\) main effect interaction; \(j\) denotes position within main effect; \(v\) denotes position within 'along' variable interaction; \(u\) denotes position within '' variable(s) interaction. Internally, AR() derives value \(\omega\) gives every element \(\beta\) marginal variance \(\tau^2\). Parameter \(\tau\) half-normal prior $$\tau \sim \text{N}^+(0, \mathtt{s}^2).$$ correlation coefficients \(\phi_1, \cdots, \phi_{\mathtt{n\_coef}}\) prior $$\phi_k \sim \text{Beta}(\mathtt{shape1}, \mathtt{shape2}).$$

title: Damped Random Walk Prior — DRW
text: DRW() used main effect, $$\beta_1 \sim \text{N}(0, \mathtt{sd}^2)$$ $$\beta_j \sim \text{N}(\phi \beta_{j-1}, \tau^2), \quad j > 1$$ used interaction, $$\beta_{u,1} \sim \text{N}(0, \mathtt{sd}^2)$$ $$\beta_{u,v} \sim \text{N}(\phi \beta_{u,v-1}, \tau^2), \quad v > 1$$ \(\pmb{\beta}\) main effect interaction; \(\phi\) damping coefficient; \(j\) denotes position within main effect; \(v\) denotes position within 'along' variable interaction; \(u\) denotes position within '' variable(s) interaction. Coefficient \(\phi\) constrained lie min max. prior distribution $$\phi = (\mathtt{max} - \mathtt{min}) \phi' - \mathtt{min}$$ $$\phi' \sim \text{Beta}(\mathtt{shape1}, \mathtt{shape2}).$$ Standard deviation \(\tau\) half-normal prior $$\tau \sim \text{N}^+(0, \mathtt{s}^2),$$ s provided user. DRW() basic structure AR1(). However, DRW(), \(\tau\) controls variance innovations, AR1() \(\tau\) controls marginal variance \(\beta_j\) \(\beta_{u,v}\).

Coefficient \(\phi\) constrained lie min max. prior distribution $$\phi = (\mathtt{max} - \mathtt{min}) \phi' - \mathtt{min}$$ $$\phi' \sim \text{Beta}(\mathtt{shape1}, \mathtt{shape2}).$$ Standard deviation \(\tau\) half-normal prior $$\tau \sim \text{N}^+(0, \mathtt{s}^2),$$ s provided user.

title: Linear Prior with Independent Normal Errors — Lin
text: Lin() used main effect, $$\beta_j = (j - (J+1)/2) \eta + \epsilon_j$$ $$\eta \sim \text{N}(\mathtt{mean\_slope}, \mathtt{sd\_slope}^2)$$ $$\epsilon_j \sim \text{N}(0, \tau^2),$$ used interaction, $$\beta_{u,v} = (v - (V + 1)/2) \eta_u + \epsilon_{u,v}$$ $$\eta_u \sim \text{N}(\mathtt{mean\_slope}, \mathtt{sd\_slope}^2)$$ $$\epsilon_{u,v} \sim \text{N}(0, \tau^2),$$ \(\pmb{\beta}\) main effect interaction; \(j\) denotes position within main effect; \(v\) denotes position within 'along' variable interaction; \(u\) denotes position within '' variable(s) interaction. Parameter \(\tau\) half-normal prior $$\tau \sim \text{N}^+(0, \mathtt{s}^2).$$ \(\mathtt{s} = 0\), model reduces $$\beta_j = (j - (J+1)/2) \eta$$ $$\eta \sim \text{N}(\mathtt{mean\_slope}, \mathtt{sd\_slope}^2)$$ $$\beta_{u,v} = (v = (V + 1)/2) \eta_u$$ $$\eta_u \sim \text{N}(\mathtt{mean\_slope}, \mathtt{sd\_slope}^2)$$.

title: Linear Prior with Autoregressive Errors — Lin_AR
text: Lin_AR() used main effect, $$\beta_1 = \alpha + \epsilon_1$$ $$\beta_j = \alpha + (j - 1) \eta + \epsilon_j, \quad j > 1$$ $$\alpha \sim \text{N}(0, 1)$$ $$\epsilon_j = \phi_1 \epsilon_{j-1} + \cdots + \phi_{\mathtt{n\_coef}} \epsilon_{j-\mathtt{n\_coef}} + \varepsilon_j$$ $$\varepsilon_j \sim \text{N}(0, \omega^2),$$ used interaction, $$\beta_{u,1} = \alpha_u + \epsilon_{u,1}$$ $$\beta_{u,v} = \eta (v - 1) + \epsilon_{u,v}, \quad v = 2, \cdots, V$$ $$\alpha_u \sim \text{N}(0, 1)$$ $$\epsilon_{u,v} = \phi_1 \epsilon_{u,v-1} + \cdots + \phi_{\mathtt{n\_coef}} \epsilon_{u,v-\mathtt{n\_coef}} + \varepsilon_{u,v},$$ $$\varepsilon_{u,v} \sim \text{N}(0, \omega^2).$$ \(\pmb{\beta}\) main effect interaction; \(j\) denotes position within main effect; \(u\) denotes position within 'along' variable interaction; \(u\) denotes position within '' variable(s) interaction. slopes priors $$\eta \sim \text{N}(\mathtt{mean\_slope}, \mathtt{sd\_slope}^2)$$ $$\eta_u \sim \text{N}(\mathtt{mean\_slope}, \mathtt{sd\_slope}^2).$$ Internally, Lin_AR() derives value \(\omega\) gives \(\epsilon_j\) \(\epsilon_{u,v}\) marginal variance \(\tau^2\). Parameter \(\tau\) half-normal prior $$\tau \sim \text{N}^+(0, \mathtt{s}^2).$$ correlation coefficients \(\phi_1, \cdots, \phi_{\mathtt{n\_coef}}\) prior $$0.5 \phi_k - 0.5 \sim \text{Beta}(\mathtt{shape1}, \mathtt{shape2}).$$

Smaller values s tend give smoother series. Argument sd controls sl size innovations random walk. Smaller values s tend give smoother series.

title: Second-Order Random Walk Prior with 'Infant' Indicator — RW2_Infant
text: RW2_Infant() used main effect, $$\beta_1 \sim \text{N}(0, 1)$$ $$\beta_2 \sim \text{N}(0, \mathtt{sd\_slope}^2)$$ $$\beta_3 \sim \text{N}(2 \beta_2, \tau^2)$$ $$\beta_j \sim \text{N}(2 \beta_{j-1} - \beta_{j-2}, \tau^2), \quad j = 3, \cdots, J$$ used interaction, $$\beta_{u,1} \sim \text{N}(0, 1)$$ $$\beta_{u,2} \sim \text{N}(0, \mathtt{sd\_slope}^2)$$ $$\beta_{u,3} \sim \text{N}(2 \beta_{u,2}, \tau^2)$$ $$\beta_{u,v} \sim \text{N}(2 \beta_{u,v-1} - \beta_{u,v-2}, \tau^2), \quad v = 3, \cdots, V$$ \(\pmb{\beta}\) main effect interaction; \(j\) denotes position within main effect; \(v\) denotes position within 'along' variable interaction; \(u\) denotes position within '' variable(s) interaction. Parameter \(\tau\) half-normal prior $$\tau \sim \text{N}^+(0, \mathtt{s}^2)$$.

text: RW2_Seas() used interaction, separate series constructed within combination '' variables. Argument s controls size innovations random walk. Smaller values s tend produce smoother series. title: Second-Order Random Walk Prior with Seasonal Effect — RW2_Seas
text: RW2_Seas() used main effect, $$\beta_j = \alpha_j + \lambda_j, \quad j = 1, \cdots, J$$ $$\alpha_1 \sim \text{N}(0, \mathtt{sd}^2)$$ $$\alpha_2 \sim \text{N}(0, \mathtt{sd\_slope}^2)$$ $$\alpha_j \sim \text{N}(2 \alpha_{j-1} - \alpha_{j-2}, \tau^2), \quad j = 3, \cdots, J$$ $$\lambda_j \sim \text{N}(0, \mathtt{sd\_seas}^2), \quad j = 1, \cdots, \mathtt{n\_seas} - 1$$ $$\lambda_j = -\sum_{s=1}^{\mathtt{n\_seas} - 1} \lambda_{j - s}, \quad j = \mathtt{n\_seas}, 2 \mathtt{n\_seas}, \cdots$$ $$\lambda_j \sim \text{N}(\lambda_{j-\mathtt{n\_seas}}, \omega^2), \quad \text{otherwise},$$ used interaction, $$\beta_{u,v} = \alpha_{u,v} + \lambda_{u,v}, \quad v = 1, \cdots, V$$ $$\alpha_{u,1} \sim \text{N}(0, \mathtt{sd}^2)$$ $$\alpha_{u,2} \sim \text{N}(0, \mathtt{sd\_slope}^2)$$ $$\alpha_{u,v} \sim \text{N}(2 \alpha_{u,v-1} - \alpha_{u,v-2}, \tau^2), \quad v = 3, \cdots, V$$ $$\lambda_{u,v} \sim \text{N}(0, \mathtt{sd\_seas}^2), \quad v = 1, \cdots, \mathtt{n\_seas} - 1$$ $$\lambda_{u,v} = -\sum_{s=1}^{\mathtt{n\_seas} - 1} \lambda_{u,v - s}, \quad v = \mathtt{n\_seas}, 2 \mathtt{n\_seas}, \cdots$$ $$\lambda_{u,v} \sim \text{N}(\lambda_{u,v-\mathtt{n\_seas}}, \omega^2), \quad \text{otherwise},$$ \(\pmb{\beta}\) main effect interaction; \(\alpha_j\) \(\alpha_{u,v}\) element random walk; \(\lambda_j\) \(\lambda_{u,v}\) element seasonal effect; \(j\) denotes position within main effect; \(v\) denotes position within 'along' variable interaction; \(u\) denotes position within '' variable(s) interaction. Parameter \(\omega\) half-normal prior $$\omega \sim \text{N}^+(0, \mathtt{s\_seas}^2)$$. s_seas set 0, \(\omega\) 0, seasonal effects fixed time. Parameter \(\tau\) half-normal prior $$\tau \sim \text{N}^+(0, \mathtt{s}^2)$$.

title: SVD-Based Prior for Age or Age-Sex Profiles — SVD
text: Case 1: Term involving age variables SVD() used age main effect, $$\pmb{\beta} = \pmb{F} \pmb{\alpha} + \pmb{g},$$ \(\pmb{\beta}\) main effect interaction involving age; \(J\) number elements \(\pmb{\beta}\); \(n\) number components SVD; \(\pmb{F}\) known matrix dimension \(J \times n\); \(\pmb{g}\) known vector \(J\) elements. \(\pmb{F}\) \(\pmb{g}\) constructed large database age-specific demographic estimates performing SVD standardizing. elements \(\pmb{\alpha}\) prior $$\alpha_k \sim \text{N}(0, 1), \quad k = 1, \cdots, K.$$ Case 2: Term involving age non-sex, non-gender variable(s) SVD() used interaction involves age involve sex gender, $$\pmb{\beta}_u = \pmb{F} \pmb{\alpha}_u + \pmb{g},$$ \(\pmb{\beta}_u\) subvector \(\pmb{\beta}\) holding values  \(u\)th combination non-age variables; \(V\) number elements \(\pmb{\beta}_u\); \(n\) number components SVD; \(\pmb{F}\) known matrix dimension \(V \times n\); \(\pmb{g}\) known vector \(V\) elements. Case 3: Term involving age, sex/gender, variables SVD() used interaction involves age sex gender, two sub-cases, depending value indep. indep TRUE, $$\pmb{\beta}_{s} = \pmb{F}_s \pmb{\alpha}_{s} + \pmb{g}_s,$$ indep FALSE, $$\pmb{\beta} = \pmb{F} \pmb{\alpha} + \pmb{g},$$ \(\pmb{\beta}\) interaction involving age sex/gender; \(\pmb{\beta}_{s}\) subvector \(\pmb{\beta}\), holding values sex/gender \(s\); \(J\) number elements \(\pmb{\beta}\); \(S\) number sexes/genders; \(n\) number components SVD; \(\pmb{F}_s\) known \((J/S) \times n\) matrix, specific sex/gender \(s\); \(\pmb{g}_s\) known vector \(J/S\) elements, specific sex/gender \(s\); \(\pmb{F}\) known \(J \times n\) matrix, values sexes/genders; \(\pmb{g}\) known vector \(J\) elements, values sexes/genders. elements \(\pmb{\alpha}_s\) \(\pmb{\alpha}\) prior $$\alpha_k \sim \text{N}(0, 1).$$ Case 4: Term involving age, sex/gender, variable(s) SVD() used interaction involves age, sex gender, variables, two sub-cases, depending value indep. indep TRUE, $$\pmb{\beta}_{u,s} = \pmb{F}_s \pmb{\alpha}_{u,s} + \pmb{g}_s,$$ indep FALSE, $$\pmb{\beta}_u = \pmb{F} \pmb{\alpha}_u + \pmb{g},$$ \(\pmb{\beta}\) interaction involving sex/gender; \(\pmb{\beta}_{u,s}\) subvector \(\pmb{\beta}\), holding values sex/gender \(s\) \(u\)th combination variables; \(V\) number elements \(\pmb{\beta}_u\); \(S\) number sexes/genders; \(n\) number components SVD; \(\pmb{F}_s\) known \((V/S) \times n\) matrix, specific sex/gender \(s\); \(\pmb{g}_s\) known vector \(V/S\) elements, specific sex/gender \(s\); \(\pmb{F}\) known \(V \times n\) matrix, values sexes/genders; \(\pmb{g}\) known vector \(V\) elements, values sexes/genders.

title: Dynamic SVD-Based Priors for Age Profiles or Age-Sex Profiles — SVD_AR
text: interaction modelled involves age time, age, sex/gender, time $$\pmb{\beta}_t = \pmb{F} \pmb{\alpha}_t + \pmb{g},$$ involves variables besides age, sex/gender, time, $$\pmb{\beta}_{u,t} = \pmb{F} \pmb{\alpha}_{u,t} + \pmb{g},$$ \(\pmb{\beta}\) interaction involving age, time, possibly sex/gender, possibly variables; \(\pmb{\beta}_t\) subvector \(\pmb{\beta}\) holding values period \(t\); \(\pmb{\beta}_{u,t}\) subvector \(\pmb{\beta}_t\) holding values  \(u\)th combination non-age, non-time, non-sex/gender variables period \(t\); \(\pmb{F}\) known matrix; \(\pmb{g}\) known vector. \(\pmb{F}\) \(\pmb{g}\) constructed large database age-specific demographic estimates applying singular value decomposition, standardizing. SVD_AR(), prior \(k\)th element \(\pmb{\alpha}_t\) \(\pmb{\alpha}_{u,t}\) $$\alpha_{k,t} = \phi_1 \alpha_{k,t-1} + \cdots + \phi_n \beta_{k,t-n} + \epsilon_{k,t}$$ $$\alpha_{k,u,t} = \phi_1 \alpha_{k,u,t-1} + \cdots + \phi_n \beta_{k,u,t-n} + \epsilon_{k,u,t};$$ SVD_AR1(), $$\alpha_{k,t} = \phi \alpha_{k,t-1} + \epsilon_{k,t}$$ $$\alpha_{k,u,t} = \phi \alpha_{k,u,t-1} + \epsilon_{k,u,t};$$ SVD_RW(), $$\alpha_{k,t} = \alpha_{k,t-1} + \epsilon_{k,t}$$ $$\alpha_{k,u,t} = \alpha_{k,u,t-1} + \epsilon_{k,u,t};$$ SVD_RW2(), $$\alpha_{k,t} = 2 \alpha_{k,t-1} - \alpha_{k,t-2} + \epsilon_{k,t}$$ $$\alpha_{k,u,t} = 2 \alpha_{k,u,t-1} - \alpha_{k,u,t-2} + \epsilon_{k,u,t};$$ SVD_DRW(), $$\alpha_{k,t} = \phi \alpha_{k,t-1} + \epsilon_{k,t}$$ $$\alpha_{k,u,t} = \phi \alpha_{k,u,t-1} + \epsilon_{k,u,t};$$ SVD_DRW2(), $$\alpha_{k,t} = \alpha_{k,t-1} + \phi (\alpha_{k,t-1} - \alpha_{k,t-2}) + \epsilon_{k,t}$$ $$\alpha_{k,u,t} = \alpha_{k,u,t-1} + \phi (\alpha_{k,u,t-1} - \alpha_{k,u,t-2}) + \epsilon_{k,u,t}.$$ SVD_AR1() SVD_DRW() almost quite identical. SVD_AR1(), variance \(\epsilon_t\) chosen \(\alpha_t\) marginal variance \(\tau^2\), SVD_DRW(), \(\epsilon_t\) variance \(\tau^2\). details time series models, see AR(), AR1(), RW(), RW2(), DRW(), DRW2().

text: Sp() used main effect, $$\pmb{\beta} = \pmb{X} \pmb{\alpha}$$ used interaction, $$\pmb{\beta}_u = \pmb{X} \pmb{\alpha}_u$$ \(\pmb{\beta}\) main effect interaction, \(J\) elements; \(\pmb{\beta}_u\) subvector \(\pmb{\beta}\) holding values  \(u\)th combination '' variables; \(J\) number elements \(\pmb{\beta}\); \(U\) number elements \(\pmb{\beta}_u\); \(X\) \(J \times n\) \(V \times n\) matrix spline basis functions; \(n\) n_comp. elements \(\pmb{\alpha}\) \(\pmb{\alpha}_u\) assumed follow second-order random walk.

title: P-Spline Prior — Sp
text: specification constraints likely change future versions bage. combinations terms priors, values intercept, main effects, interactions weakly identified. instance, may possible increase value intercept reduce value remaining terms model effect predicted rates tiny effect prior probabilities. weak identifiability typically harmless. However, applications, trying obtain interpretable values main effects interactions, can helpful increase identifiability use constraints, specified con argument. Current options con : "none" constraints. default. "" used interaction terms include 'along' '' dimensions. Within value 'along' dimension, terms across '' dimension constrained sum 0.

title: P-Spline Prior — Sp
text: Eilers, P.H.C. Marx B. (1996). "Flexible smoothing B-splines penalties". Statistical Science. 11 (2): 89–121.

title: P-Spline Prior — Sp

text: tibble, original data plus one following columns: .<outcome> Corrected extended version outcome variable, applications outcome variable missing values, data model used. .observed 'Direct' estimates rates probabilities, ie counts divided exposure size (Poisson binomial models.) .fitted Draws rates, probabilities, means. .expected Draws expected values rates probabilities (Poisson include exposure, binomial models.) title: Extract Data and Modeled Values — augment.bage_mod

title: Extract Values for Hyper-Parameters — components.bage_mod
text: components() typically called fitted model. case, values returned draws joint posterior distribution hyper-parameters model. components() can, however, called unfitted model. case, values returned draws joint prior distribution. words, values incorporate model priors, exposure, size, weights argument, observed outcomes.

title: Extract Values for Hyper-Parameters — components.bage_mod
text: Internally, models created mod_norm() fitted using transformed versions outcome weights variables. default, components() used models, returns values .fitted based transformed versions. instead obtain values "effect", "trend", "season", "error" "disp" based untransformed versions, set original_scale TRUE.

See details. vars_inner Names variables use inner model method "inner-outer". NULL(default)vars_inner` age, sex/gender, time variables. optimizer optimizer use. Current choices "multi", "nlminb", "BFGS", "CG". Default "multi". See details. quiet Whether suppress messages optimizer. Default TRUE. max_jitter Maximum quantity add diagonal precision matrix, Cholesky factorization failing. Default 0.0001. start_oldpar Whether optimizer start previous estimates. Used fit() called fitted model. Default FALSE. ... currently used.

title: Fit a Model — fit.bage_mod
text: bage_mod object

title: Fit a Model — fit.bage_mod
text: method "standard" (default), parameters, lowest-level rates, probabilities, means jointly estimated within TMB. method "inner-outer", estimation carried multiple steps, , large models, can sometimes reduce computation times. Step 1, model using inner variables fitted data. Step 2, model using outer variables fitted data. Step 3, values dispersion calculated. Parameter estimates steps 1, 2, 3 combined.

title: Fit a Model — fit.bage_mod
text: choices optimizer argument : "multi" Try "nlminb", fails, restart parameter values "nlminb" stopped, using "BFGS". default. "nlminb" stats::nlminb() "BFGS" stats::optim() using method "BFGS". "GC" stats::optim() using method "CG" (conjugate gradient).

title: Fit a Model — fit.bage_mod
text: Sampling posterior distribution requires performing Cholesky factorization precision matrix returned TMB. factorization sometimes fails numerical problems. Adding small quantity diagonal precision matrix can alleviate numerical problems, potentially reducing accuracy. Cholesky factorization initially fails, bage try progressively larger quantities added diagonal, maximum set max_jitter. Increasing value max_jitter can help suppress numerical problems. safer strategy, however, simplify model, use informative priors.

title: Fit a Model — fit.bage_mod
text: version 0.9.8 bage, fit() always aggregated across cells identical values predictor variables formula (ie variables right ~) fitting. instance, dataset contained deaths population disaggregated age sex, model formula deaths ~ age, fit() aggregate deaths population within age category fitting model. version 0.9.9, fit() aggregates across cells identical values data model used, model Poisson dispersion set 0 normal. Note change behavior effect models, since models include variables used classify outcomes.

title: Use a Model to Make a Forecast — forecast.bage_mod
text: Internally, steps involved forecast : Forecast time-varying main effects interactions, e.g. time main effect, age-time interaction. Combine forecasts time-varying main effects interactions non-time-varying parameters, e.g. age effects dispersion. Use combined parameters generate values rates, probabilities means. Optionally, generate values outcome variable. forecast() generates values outcome variable , output "augment", value supplied newdata, newdata included value exposure, size, weights variable (except exposure = 1 weights = 1 original call mod_pois() mod_norm()). Mathematical Details gives details internal calculations forecasting.

title: Use a Model to Make a Forecast — forecast.bage_mod
text: output "augment" (default), return value forecast() looks like output function augment(). output "components", return value looks like output components(). include_estimates FALSE (default), output forecast() excludes values time-varying parameters period covered data. include_estimates TRUE, output includes values. Setting include_estimates TRUE can helpful creating graphs combine estimates forecasts.

text: forecast() typically used fitted model, .e. model parameter values estimated data. resulting forecasts reflect data priors. forecast() can, however, used unfitted model. case, forecasts based entirely priors. title: Specify a Binomial Model — mod_binom
text: Specify model outcome drawn binomial distribution.

title: Specify a Binomial Model — mod_binom
code: mod_binom(formula, data, size)

title: Specify a Binomial Model — mod_binom
text: formula R formula, specifying outcome predictors. data data frame containing outcome predictor variables, number trials. size Name variable giving number trials (without quote marks.)

title: Specify a Binomial Model — mod_binom
text: object class bage_mod.

title: Specify a Binomial Model — mod_binom
text: model hierarchical. probabilities binomial distribution described prior model formed dimensions age, sex, time. terms dimension models, described priors. priors defaults, depend type term (eg intercept, age main effect, age-time interaction.)

title: Specify a Binomial Model — mod_binom
text: likelihood $$y_i \sim \text{binomial}(\gamma_i; w_i)$$ subscript \(\) identifies combination classifying variables, age, sex, time; \(y_i\) count, number births, age, sex, region; \(\gamma_i\) probability 'success'; \(w_i\) number trials. probabilities \(\gamma_i\) assumed drawn beta distribution $$y_i \sim \text{Beta}(\xi^{-1} \mu_i, \xi^{-1} (1 - \mu_i))$$ \(\mu_i\) expected value \(\gamma_i\); \(\xi\) governs dispersion (ie variance.) Expected value \(\mu_i\) equals, logit scale, sum terms formed classifying variables, $$\text{logit} \mu_i = \sum_{m=0}^{M} \beta_{j_i^m}^{(m)}$$ \(\beta^{0}\) intercept; \(\beta^{(m)}\), \(m = 1, \dots, M\), main effect interaction; \(j_i^m\) element \(\beta^{(m)}\) associated cell \(\). \(\beta^{(m)}\) given priors, described priors. \(\xi\) exponential prior mean 1. Non-default values mean can specified  set_disp(). model \(\mu_i\) can also include covariates, described set_covariates().

title: Specify a Binomial Model — mod_binom
code: mod <- mod_binom(oneperson ~ age:region + age:year,                  data = nzl_households,                  size = total)

title: Specify a Normal Model — mod_norm
code: mod_norm(formula, data, weights = NULL)

title: Specify a Normal Model — mod_norm
text: formula R formula, specifying outcome predictors. data data frame containing outcome, predictor, , optionally, weights variables. weights Name weights variable, 1, formula. See details.

title: Specify a Normal Model — mod_norm
text: object class bage_mod_norm.

title: Specify a Normal Model — mod_norm
text: model hierarchical. means normal distribution described prior model formed dimensions age, sex, time. terms dimension models, described priors. priors defaults, depend type term (eg intercept, age main effect, age-time interaction.)

title: Specify a Normal Model — mod_norm
text: Internally, mod_norm() scales outcome variable mean 0 standard deviation 1, scales weights mean 1. scaling allows mod_norm() use menu priors mod_pois() mod_binom(). augment() always returns values original scale, rather transformed scale. components() default returns values transformed scale. original_scale TRUE, returns types values original scale. See components() details.

title: Specify a Normal Model — mod_norm
text: three options creating unweighted model: supply value weights variable; set weights equal NULL; set weights equal 1, though option deprecated, eventually removed. create weighted model, supply name weighting variable data, quoted unquoted.

title: Specify a Normal Model — mod_norm
text: likelihood $$y_i \sim \text{N}(\gamma_i, w_i^{-1} \sigma^2)$$ subscript \(\) identifies combination classifying variables, age, sex, time, \(y_i\) value outcome variable, \(w_i\) weight. applications, \(w_i\) set 1 \(\). Internally, bage works standardized versions \(\gamma_i\) \(\sigma^2\): $$\mu_i = (\gamma_i - \bar{y}) / s$$ $$\xi^2 = \sigma^2 / (\bar{w} s^2)$$ $$\bar{y} = \sum_{=1}^n y_i / n$$ $$s = \sqrt{\sum_{=1}^n (y_i - \bar{y})^2 / (n-1)}$$ $$\bar{w} = \sum_{=1}^n w_i / n$$ Mean parameter \(\mu_i\) modelled sum terms formed classifying variables covariates, $$\mu_i = \sum_{m=0}^{M} \beta_{j_i^m}^{(m)}$$ \(\beta^{0}\) intercept; \(\beta^{(m)}\), \(m = 1, \dots, M\), main effect interaction; \(j_i^m\) element \(\beta^{(m)}\) associated cell \(\), \(\beta^{(m)}\) given priors, described priors. \(\xi\) exponential prior mean 1. Non-default values mean can specified set_disp(). model \(\mu_i\) can also include covariates, described set_covariates().

title: Specify a Normal Model — mod_norm
code: ## model without weights mod <- mod_norm(value ~ diag:age + year,                 data = nld_expenditure)  ## model with weights nld_expenditure$wt <- sqrt(nld_expenditure$value) mod <- mod_norm(value ~ diag:age + year,                 data = nld_expenditure,                 weights = wt)

title: Specify a Poisson Model — mod_pois
text: formula R formula, specifying outcome predictors. data data frame containing outcome, predictor, , optionally, exposure variables. exposure Name exposure variable NULL. See details.

title: Specify a Poisson Model — mod_pois
text: object class bage_mod_pois.

title: Specify a Poisson Model — mod_pois
text: model hierarchical. rates Poisson distribution described prior model formed dimensions age, sex, time. terms dimension models, described priors. priors defaults, depend type term (eg intercept, age main effect, age-time interaction.)

title: Specify a Poisson Model — mod_pois
text: exposure argument can take three forms: name variable data, without quote marks, eg "population" population; NULL, case pure "counts" model exposure, produced; number 1, case pure "counts" model also produced (though option deprecated, eventially removed).

title: Specify a Poisson Model — mod_pois
text: likelihood $$y_i \sim \text{Poisson}(\gamma_i w_i)$$ subscript \(\) identifies combination classifying variables, age, sex, time; \(y_i\) outcome, deaths; \(\gamma_i\) rates; \(w_i\) exposure. applications, obvious population risk. cases, exposure \(w_i\) can set 1 \(\). rates \(\gamma_i\) assumed drawn gamma distribution $$y_i \sim \text{Gamma}(\xi^{-1}, (\xi \mu_i)^{-1})$$ \(\mu_i\) expected value \(\gamma_i\); \(\xi\) governs dispersion (.e. variation), lower values implying less dispersion. Expected value \(\mu_i\) equals, log scale, sum terms formed classifying variables, $$\log \mu_i = \sum_{m=0}^{M} \beta_{j_i^m}^{(m)}$$ \(\beta^{0}\) intercept; \(\beta^{(m)}\), \(m = 1, \dots, M\), main effect interaction; \(j_i^m\) element \(\beta^{(m)}\) associated cell \(\). \(\beta^{(m)}\) given priors, described priors. \(\xi\) exponential prior mean 1. Non-default values mean can specified  set_disp(). model \(\mu_i\) can also include covariates, described set_covariates().

title: Specify a Poisson Model — mod_pois
code: ## model with exposure mod <- mod_pois(injuries ~ age:sex + ethnicity + year,                 data = nzl_injuries,                 exposure = popn)  ## model without exposure mod <- mod_pois(injuries ~ age:sex + ethnicity + year,                 data = nzl_injuries,                 exposure = NULL)

code: mod <- mod_pois(injuries ~ age + sex + year,                 data = nzl_injuries,                 exposure = popn)  ## print unfitted model mod #>  #>     ------ Unfitted Poisson model ------ #>  #>    injuries ~ age + sex + year #>  #>                  exposure: popn #>  #>         term  prior along n_par n_par_free #>  (Intercept) NFix()     -     1          1 #>          age   RW()   age    12         12 #>          sex NFix()     -     2          2 #>         year   RW()  year    19         19 #>  #>  disp: mean = 1 #>  #>  n_draw var_time var_age var_sexgender #>    1000     year     age           sex #>   mod <- fit(mod) #> Building log-posterior function... #> Finding maximum... #> Drawing values for hyper-parameters...  ## print fitted model mod #>  #>     ------ Fitted Poisson model ------ #>  #>    injuries ~ age + sex + year #>  #>                  exposure: popn #>  #>         term  prior along n_par n_par_free std_dev #>  (Intercept) NFix()     -     1          1       - #>          age   RW()   age    12         12    0.76 #>          sex NFix()     -     2          2    0.71 #>         year   RW()  year    19         19    0.09 #>  #>  disp: mean = 1 #>  #>  n_draw var_time var_age var_sexgender optimizer #>    1000     year     age           sex    nlminb #>  #>  time_total time_max time_draw iter converged                    message #>        0.50     0.21      0.25   12      TRUE   relative convergence (4) #>

what: Priors for Intercept, Main Effects, Interactions — priors
title: Priors for Intercept, Main Effects, Interactions — priors
text: models created functions mod_pois(), mod_binom(), mod_norm() always include intercept, typically include main effects interactions formed variables input data. models, instance include age effect, many include interaction age sex/gender, age time. intercept, main effects, interactions prior models capture expected behavior term. Current choices priors summarised table . Priors 'forecast' yes can used forecasts time-varying terms age-time interactions. Priors 'along' yes distinguish 'along' '' dimensions.

title: Priors for Intercept, Main Effects, Interactions — priors
text: rule selecting default prior term : term less 3 elements, use NFix(); otherwise, term involves time, use RW(), time `along' dimension; otherwise, term involves age, use RW(), age `along' dimension; otherwise, use N().

title: Create Replicate Data — replicate_data
text: x fitted model, typically created calling mod_pois(), mod_binom(), mod_norm(), fit(). condition_on Parameters condition . Either "expected" "fitted". See details. n Number replicate datasets create. Default 19.

title: Create Replicate Data — replicate_data
text: tibble following structure:

title: Create Replicate Data — replicate_data
text: Use n draws posterior distribution model parameters generate n simulated datasets. model working well, simulated datasets look similar actual dataset.

title: Create Replicate Data — replicate_data
text: Poisson binomial models include dispersion terms (default), two options constructing replicate data. condition_on "fitted", replicate data created () drawing values posterior distribution rates probabilities (\(\gamma_i\) defined mod_pois() mod_binom()), (ii)  conditional rates probabilities, drawing values outcome variable. condition_on "expected", replicate data created () drawing values hyper-parameters governing rates probabilities (\(\mu_i\) \(\xi\) defined mod_pois() mod_binom()), (ii) conditional hyper-parameters, drawing values rates probabilities, finally (iii) conditional rates probabilities, drawing values outcome variable. `"expected" option possible Poisson binomial models, dispersion non-zero. default condition_on "expected", cases feasible. "expected" option provides severe test model "fitted" option, since "fitted" values weighted averages "expected" values original data.

title: Create Replicate Data — replicate_data
text: data model provided outcome variable, creation replicate data include step errors added outcomes. instance, rr3 data model used, replicate_data() rounds outcomes base 3.

title: Create Replicate Data — replicate_data
code: mod <- mod_pois(injuries ~ age:sex + ethnicity + year,                 data = nzl_injuries,                 exposure = 1) |>   fit() #> Building log-posterior function... #> Finding maximum... #> Drawing values for hyper-parameters...  rep_data <- mod |>   replicate_data()  library(dplyr) rep_data |>   group_by(.replicate) |>   count(wt = injuries) #> # A tibble: 20 × 2 #> # Groups:   .replicate [20] #>    .replicate       n #>    <fct>        <dbl> #>  1 Original     21588 #>  2 Replicate 1  21088 #>  3 Replicate 2  20918 #>  4 Replicate 3  21963 #>  5 Replicate 4  20803 #>  6 Replicate 5  20738 #>  7 Replicate 6  21066 #>  8 Replicate 7  21711 #>  9 Replicate 8  20784 #> 10 Replicate 9  20277 #> 11 Replicate 10 20600 #> 12 Replicate 11 21293 #> 13 Replicate 12 21792 #> 14 Replicate 13 21481 #> 15 Replicate 14 21390 #> 16 Replicate 15 20504 #> 17 Replicate 16 21521 #> 18 Replicate 17 21354 #> 19 Replicate 18 21881 #> 20 Replicate 19 22475  ## when the overall model includes an rr3 data model, ## replicate data are rounded to base 3 mod_pois(injuries ~ age:sex + ethnicity + year,          data = nzl_injuries,          exposure = popn) |>   set_datamod_outcome_rr3() |>   fit() |>   replicate_data() #> Building log-posterior function... #> Finding maximum... #> Drawing values for hyper-parameters... #> # A tibble: 18,240 × 7 #>    .replicate age   sex    ethnicity  year injuries  popn #>    <fct>      <fct> <chr>  <chr>     <int>    <dbl> <int> #>  1 Original   0-4   Female Maori      2000       12 35830 #>  2 Original   5-9   Female Maori      2000        6 35120 #>  3 Original   10-14 Female Maori      2000        3 32830 #>  4 Original   15-19 Female Maori      2000        6 27130 #>  5 Original   20-24 Female Maori      2000        6 24380 #>  6 Original   25-29 Female Maori      2000        6 24160 #>  7 Original   30-34 Female Maori      2000       12 22560 #>  8 Original   35-39 Female Maori      2000        3 22230 #>  9 Original   40-44 Female Maori      2000        6 18130 #> 10 Original   45-49 Female Maori      2000        6 13770 #> # ℹ 18,230 more rows

what: Simulation Study of a Model — report_sim
title: Simulation Study of a Model — report_sim
text: Use simulated data assess performance estimation model.

title: Simulation Study of a Model — report_sim
code: report_sim(   mod_est,   mod_sim = NULL,   method = c("standard", "inner-outer"),   vars_inner = NULL,   n_sim = 100,   point_est_fun = c("median", "mean"),   widths = c(0.5, 0.95),   report_type = c("short", "long", "full"),   n_core = 1 )

title: Simulation Study of a Model — report_sim
text: mod_est model whose performance assessed. object class bage_mod. mod_sim model used generate simulated data. value supplied, mod_est used. method Estimation method used mod_est. See fit(). vars_inner Variables used inner model "inner-outer"estimation method. See fit(). n_sim Number sets simulated data use. Default 100. point_est_fun Name function use calculate point estimates. options "mean" "median". default "mean". widths Widths credible intervals. vector values interval (0, 1]. Default c(0.5, 0.95). report_type Amount detail return value. Options "short" "long". Default "short". n_core Number cores use parallel processing. n_core 1 (default), parallel processing done.

title: Simulation Study of a Model — report_sim
text: named list tibble called "components" tibble called "augment".

title: Simulation Study of a Model — report_sim
text: interface report_sim() still development may change future.

title: Simulation Study of a Model — report_sim
code: ## results random, so set seed set.seed(0)  ## make data - outcome variable (deaths here) ## needs to be present, but is not used data <- data.frame(region = c("A", "B", "C", "D", "E"),                    population = c(100, 200, 300, 400, 500),                    deaths = NA)  ## simulation with estimation model same as ## data-generating model mod_est <- mod_pois(deaths ~ region,                     data = data,                     exposure = population) |>   set_prior(`(Intercept)` ~ Known(0)) report_sim(mod_est = mod_est,            n_sim = 10) ## in practice should use larger value #> Building log-posterior function... #> Finding maximum... #> Drawing values for hyper-parameters... #> Building log-posterior function... #> Finding maximum... #> Drawing values for hyper-parameters... #> Building log-posterior function... #> Finding maximum... #> Drawing values for hyper-parameters... #> Building log-posterior function... #> Finding maximum... #> Drawing values for hyper-parameters... #> Building log-posterior function... #> Finding maximum... #> Drawing values for hyper-parameters... #> Building log-posterior function... #> Finding maximum... #> Drawing values for hyper-parameters... #> Building log-posterior function... #> Finding maximum... #> Drawing values for hyper-parameters... #> Building log-posterior function... #> Finding maximum... #> Drawing values for hyper-parameters... #> Building log-posterior function... #> Finding maximum... #> Drawing values for hyper-parameters... #> Building log-posterior function... #> Finding maximum... #> Drawing values for hyper-parameters... #> $components #> # A tibble: 4 × 7 #>   term        component     .error .cover_50 .cover_95 .length_50 .length_95 #>   <chr>       <chr>          <dbl>     <dbl>     <dbl>      <dbl>      <dbl> #> 1 (Intercept) effect     0               1        1         0           0    #> 2 region      effect     0.0448          0.6      0.92      0.828       2.40 #> 3 region      hyper     -0.0000343       0.5      0.8       0.506       1.73 #> 4 disp        disp      -0.317           0.4      0.9       0.630       2.64 #>  #> $augment #> # A tibble: 2 × 7 #>   .var      .observed  .error .cover_50 .cover_95 .length_50 .length_95 #>   <chr>         <dbl>   <dbl>     <dbl>     <dbl>      <dbl>      <dbl> #> 1 .fitted        3.62  0.0102      0.44      0.94      0.116      0.342 #> 2 .expected      3.62 -0.683       0.6       0.92      2.45      10.5   #>   ## simulation with estimation model different ## from data-generating model mod_sim <- mod_est |>   set_prior(region ~ N(s = 2)) report_sim(mod_est = mod_est,            mod_sim = mod_sim,            n_sim = 10) #> Building log-posterior function... #> Finding maximum... #> Drawing values for hyper-parameters... #> Building log-posterior function... #> Finding maximum... #> Drawing values for hyper-parameters... #> Building log-posterior function... #> Finding maximum... #> Drawing values for hyper-parameters... #> Building log-posterior function... #> Finding maximum... #> Drawing values for hyper-parameters... #> Building log-posterior function... #> Finding maximum... #> Drawing values for hyper-parameters... #> Building log-posterior function... #> Finding maximum... #> Drawing values for hyper-parameters... #> Building log-posterior function... #> Finding maximum... #> Drawing values for hyper-parameters... #> Building log-posterior function... #> Finding maximum... #> Drawing values for hyper-parameters... #> Building log-posterior function... #> Finding maximum... #> Drawing values for hyper-parameters... #> Building log-posterior function... #> Finding maximum... #> Drawing values for hyper-parameters... #> $components #> # A tibble: 4 × 7 #>   term        component .error .cover_50 .cover_95 .length_50 .length_95 #>   <chr>       <chr>      <dbl>     <dbl>     <dbl>      <dbl>      <dbl> #> 1 (Intercept) effect     0           1        1         0           0    #> 2 region      effect     0.205       0.5      0.92      1.03        2.93 #> 3 region      hyper     -0.502       0.3      0.8       0.595       1.97 #> 4 disp        disp      -0.119       0.4      0.7       0.915       4.35 #>  #> $augment #> # A tibble: 2 × 7 #>   .var      .observed  .error .cover_50 .cover_95 .length_50 .length_95 #>   <chr>         <dbl>   <dbl>     <dbl>     <dbl>      <dbl>      <dbl> #> 1 .fitted        129.  -0.187      0.44      0.96      0.339      0.984 #> 2 .expected      129. -25.2        0.5       0.92    105.       556.    #>

title: Specify RR3 Confidentialization — set_confidential_rr3
text: Specify confidentialization procedure outcome variable randomly rounded multiple 3.

title: Specify RR3 Confidentialization — set_confidential_rr3
code: set_confidential_rr3(mod)

title: Specify RR3 Confidentialization — set_confidential_rr3
text: mod object class "bage_mod", created mod_pois(), mod_binom(), mod_norm().

title: Specify RR3 Confidentialization — set_confidential_rr3
text: revised version mod.

title: Specify RR3 Confidentialization — set_confidential_rr3
text: set_confidential_rr3() can used Poisson binomial models (created mod_pois() mod_binom().) Random rounding base 3 (RR3) confidentialization technique sometimes applied statistical agencies. procedure randomly-rounding integer value \(n\) follows: \(n\) divisible 3, leave unchanged dividing \(n\) 3 leaves remainder 1, round (subtract 1) probability 2/3, round (add 2) probability 1/3. dividing \(n\) 3 leaves remainder 1, round (subtract 2) probability 1/3, round (add 1) probability 2/3. set_confidential_rr3() applied fitted model, set_confidential_rr3() unfits model, deleting existing estimates.

title: Specify RR3 Confidentialization — set_confidential_rr3
code: ## 'injuries' variable in 'nzl_injuries' dataset ## has been randomly rounded to base 3 mod <- mod_pois(injuries ~ age:sex + ethnicity + year,                 data = nzl_injuries,                 exposure = popn) |>   set_confidential_rr3() |>   fit() #> Building log-posterior function... #> Finding maximum... #> Drawing values for hyper-parameters...

title: Specify Covariates — set_covariates
text: Add covariates model.

title: Specify Covariates — set_covariates
code: set_covariates(mod, formula)

title: Specify Covariates — set_covariates
text: mod object class "bage_mod", created mod_pois(), mod_binom(), mod_norm(). formula one-sided R formula, specifying covariates.

title: Specify Covariates — set_covariates
text: modified version mod

title: Specify Covariates — set_covariates
text: set_covariates() applied model already covariates, set_covariates() deletes existing covariates. set_covariates() applied fitted model, set_covariates() unfits model, deleting existing estimates.

title: Specify Covariates — set_covariates
text: variables contained formula argument set_covariates() dataset supplied original call mod_pois(), mod_binom(), mod_norm(). set_covariates() processes covariate data adding model: numeric variables standardized, using x <- scale(x). Categorical variables converted sets indicator variables, using treatment contrasts. instance, variable x categories "high", "medium", "low", converted two indicator variables, one called xmedium one called xlow.

title: Specify Covariates — set_covariates
text: model includes covariates, quantity $$\pmb{Z} \pmb{\zeta}$$ added linear predictor, \(\pmb{Z}\) matrix standardized covariates, \(\pmb{\zeta}\) vector coefficients. elements \(\pmb{\zeta}\) prior $$\zeta_p \sim \text{N}(0, 1)$$.

title: Specify Covariates — set_covariates
code: ## create a COVID covariate library(dplyr, warn.conflicts = FALSE) births <- kor_births |>   mutate(is_covid = time %in% 2020:2022) mod <- mod_pois(births ~ age * region + time,                 data = births,                 exposure = popn) |>   set_covariates(~ is_covid) mod #>  #>     ------ Unfitted Poisson model ------ #>  #>    births ~ age * region + time #>  #>                  exposure: popn #>  #>         term  prior along n_par n_par_free #>  (Intercept) NFix()     -     1          1 #>          age   RW()   age     9          9 #>       region    N()     -    16         16 #>         time   RW()  time    13         13 #>   age:region   RW()   age   144        144 #>  #>  covariates: ~is_covid #>  #>  disp: mean = 1 #>  #>  n_draw var_time var_age #>    1000     time     age #>

title: Specify Exposure Data Model — set_datamod_exposure
text: Specify data model exposure variable Poisson model. data model assumes , within cell, observed exposure drawn Inverse-Gamma distribution. model, E[ expected exposure | true exposure ] = true exposure sd[ expected exposure | true exposure ] = cv \(\times\) true exposure cv coefficient variation parameter.

title: Specify Exposure Data Model — set_datamod_exposure
code: set_datamod_exposure(mod, cv)

title: Specify Exposure Data Model — set_datamod_exposure
text: mod object class "bage_mod_pois", created mod_pois(). cv Coefficient variation measurement errors exposure. single number, data frame variable called "cv" one '' variables.

title: Specify Exposure Data Model — set_datamod_exposure
text: revised version mod.

title: Specify Exposure Data Model — set_datamod_exposure
text: exposure data model, cv, coefficient variation, depend true exposure. implies errors fall, relative terms, population rises. Unlike sampling errors, measurement errors get averaged away large populations. exposure data model assumes exposure variable unbiased. fact evidence biases, evidence used create de-biased version variable (eg one estimated biases subtracted) supply mod_pois(). set_datamod_exposure() can used Poisson model rates dispersion rates set zero. dispersion rates can set explicitly zero using set_disp(), though set_datamod_exposure() also .

title: Specify Exposure Data Model — set_datamod_exposure
text: cv can single number, case value used cells. cv can also data frame variable called "cv" one columns '' variables. instance,  cv   implies coefficient variation 0.01 females 0.012 males. See example coefficient variation based aggregated age groups.
code: data.frame(sex = c("Female", "Male"),            cv = c(0.01, 0.012))

title: Specify Exposure Data Model — set_datamod_exposure
text: model observed exposure $$w_i^{\text{obs}} \sim \text{InvGamma}(2 + d_{g \lbrack \rbrack }^{-1}, (1 + d_{g \lbrack \rbrack }^{-1}) w_i^{\text{true}})$$ \(w_i^{\text{obs}}\) observed exposure cell \(\) (exposure argument mod_pois()); \(w_i^{\text{true}}\) true exposure cell \(\); \(d_{g\lbrack \rbrack }\) value dispersion applied cell \(\). cv \(\sqrt{d_g}\).

title: Specify Exposure Data Model — set_datamod_exposure
code: ## specify model mod <- mod_pois(injuries ~ age * sex + year,                 data = nzl_injuries,                 exposure = popn) |>   set_disp(mean = 0) |>   set_datamod_exposure(cv = 0.025)  ## fit the model mod <- mod |>   fit() #> Building log-posterior function... #> Finding maximum... #> Drawing values for hyper-parameters... mod #>  #>     ------ Fitted Poisson model ------ #>  #>    injuries ~ age * sex + year #>  #>                  exposure: popn #>                data model: exposure #>  #>         term  prior along n_par n_par_free std_dev #>  (Intercept) NFix()     -     1          1       - #>          age   RW()   age    12         12    0.71 #>          sex NFix()     -     2          2    0.11 #>         year   RW()  year    19         19    0.09 #>      age:sex   RW()   age    24         24    0.43 #>  #>  n_draw var_time var_age var_sexgender optimizer #>    1000     year     age           sex    nlminb #>  #>  time_total time_max time_draw iter converged                    message #>        0.50     0.22      0.24   12      TRUE   relative convergence (4) #>   ## examine results - note the new variable ## '.popn' with estimates of the true ## population aug <- mod |>   augment() #> ℹ Adding variable `.popn` with true values for `popn`.  ## allow different cv's for each sex cv_sex <- data.frame(sex = c("Female", "Male"),                      cv = c(0.03, 0.02)) mod <- mod |>   set_datamod_exposure(cv = cv_sex) #> → Replacing existing "exposure" data model with new "exposure" data model mod #>  #>     ------ Unfitted Poisson model ------ #>  #>    injuries ~ age * sex + year #>  #>                  exposure: popn #>                data model: exposure #>  #>         term  prior along n_par n_par_free #>  (Intercept) NFix()     -     1          1 #>          age   RW()   age    12         12 #>          sex NFix()     -     2          2 #>         year   RW()  year    19         19 #>      age:sex   RW()   age    24         24 #>  #>  n_draw var_time var_age var_sexgender optimizer #>    1000     year     age           sex    nlminb #>   ## our outcome variable is confidentialized, ## so we recognize that in the model too mod <- mod |>   set_confidential_rr3() mod #>  #>     ------ Unfitted Poisson model ------ #>  #>    injuries ~ age * sex + year #>  #>                  exposure: popn #>                data model: exposure #>       confidentialization: rr3 #>  #>         term  prior along n_par n_par_free #>  (Intercept) NFix()     -     1          1 #>          age   RW()   age    12         12 #>          sex NFix()     -     2          2 #>         year   RW()  year    19         19 #>      age:sex   RW()   age    24         24 #>  #>  n_draw var_time var_age var_sexgender optimizer #>    1000     year     age           sex    nlminb #>   ## now a model where everyone aged 0-49 ## receives one value for cv, and ## everyone aged 50+ receives another library(poputils) ## for 'age_upper()' library(dplyr, warn.conflicts = FALSE) nzl_injuries_age <- nzl_injuries |>   mutate(age_group = if_else(age_upper(age) < 50,                              "0-49",                              "50+")) cv_age <- data.frame(age_group = c("0-49", "50+"),                      cv = c(0.05, 0.01)) mod <- mod_pois(injuries ~ age * sex + year,                 data = nzl_injuries_age,                 exposure = popn) |>   set_disp(mean = 0) |>   set_datamod_exposure(cv = cv_age)

title: Specify Miscount Data Model — set_datamod_miscount
text: Specify data model outcome Poisson model, outcome subject undercount overcount.

title: Specify Miscount Data Model — set_datamod_miscount
code: set_datamod_miscount(mod, prob, rate)

title: Specify Miscount Data Model — set_datamod_miscount
text: mod object class "bage_mod_pois", created mod_pois(). prob prior probability person event target population correctly enumerated. data frame variable called "mean", variable called "disp", , optionally, one '' variables. rate prior overcoverage rate. data frame variable called "mean", variable called "disp", , optionally, one '' variables.

title: Specify Miscount Data Model — set_datamod_miscount
text: revised version mod.

title: Specify Miscount Data Model — set_datamod_miscount
text: miscount data model essentially combination undercount overcount data models. assumes reported outcome sum two quantities: Units target population, undercounted People events belonging target population, unit's inclusion probability less 1. Overcount People events belong target population, counted . , instance, census enumerates 91 people true population 100, also mistakenly enumerates 6 people, true value outcome variable 100 value undercounted target population 91, value overcount 6, observed value outcome variable 91 + 6 = 97.

title: Specify Miscount Data Model — set_datamod_miscount
text: prob argument specifies prior distribution probability person event target population included reported outcome. prob data frame variable called "mean", variable called "disp", , optionally, one '' variables. instance,  prob   implies expected value inclusion probability 0.95 females 0.92 males, slightly uncertainty females males.
code: data.frame(sex = c("Female", "Male"),            mean = c(0.95, 0.92),            disp = c(0.02, 0.015))

title: Specify Miscount Data Model — set_datamod_miscount
text: rate argument specifies prior distribution overcoverage rate. rate data frame variable called "mean", variable called "disp", , optionally, one '' variables. instance,  rate   implies expected value overcoverage rate 0.03, dispersion 0.1. Since '' variables included, mean dispersion values applied cells.
code: data.frame(mean = 0.03, disp = 0.1)

title: Specify Miscount Data Model — set_datamod_miscount
text: model observed outcome $$y_i^{\text{obs}} = u_i + v_i$$ $$u_i \sim \text{Binomial}(y_i^{\text{true}}, \pi_{g[]})$$ $$v_i \sim \text{Poisson}(\kappa_{h[]} \gamma_i w_i)$$ $$\pi_g \sim \text{Beta}(m_g^{(\pi)} / d_g^{(\pi)}, (1-m_g^{(\pi)}) / d_g^{(\pi)})$$ $$\kappa_h \sim \text{Gamma}(1/d_h^{(\kappa)}, 1/(d_h^{(\kappa)} m_h^{(\kappa)}))$$ \(y_i^{\text{obs}}\) observed outcome cell \(\); \(y_i^{\text{true}}\) true outcome cell \(\); \(\gamma_i\) rate cell \(\); \(w_i\) exposure cell \(\); \(\pi_{g[]}\) probability member target population cell \(\) correctly enumerated cell; \(\kappa_{h[]}\) overcoverage rate cell \(\); \(m_g^{(\pi)}\) expected value \(\pi_g\) (specified via prob); \(d_g^{(\pi)}\) disperson \(\pi_g\) (specified via prob); \(m_h^{(\kappa)}\) expected value \(\kappa_h\) (specified via rate); \(d_h^{(\kappa)}\) disperson \(\kappa_h\) (specified via rate).

title: Specify Miscount Data Model — set_datamod_miscount
code: ## specify 'prob' and 'rate' prob <- data.frame(sex = c("Female", "Male"),                    mean = c(0.95, 0.97),                    disp = c(0.05, 0.05)) rate <- data.frame(mean = 0.03, disp = 0.15)  ## specify model mod <- mod_pois(divorces ~ age * sex + time,                 data = nzl_divorces,                 exposure = population) |>   set_datamod_miscount(prob = prob, rate = rate) mod #>  #>     ------ Unfitted Poisson model ------ #>  #>    divorces ~ age * sex + time #>  #>                  exposure: population #>                data model: miscount #>  #>         term  prior along n_par n_par_free #>  (Intercept) NFix()     -     1          1 #>          age   RW()   age    11         11 #>          sex NFix()     -     2          2 #>         time   RW()  time    11         11 #>      age:sex   RW()   age    22         22 #>  #>  disp: mean = 1 #>  #>  n_draw var_time var_age var_sexgender #>    1000     time     age           sex #>   ## fit model mod <- mod |>   fit() #> Building log-posterior function... #> Finding maximum... #> Drawing values for hyper-parameters... mod #>  #>     ------ Fitted Poisson model ------ #>  #>    divorces ~ age * sex + time #>  #>                  exposure: population #>                data model: miscount #>  #>         term  prior along n_par n_par_free std_dev #>  (Intercept) NFix()     -     1          1       - #>          age   RW()   age    11         11    2.00 #>          sex NFix()     -     2          2    0.36 #>         time   RW()  time    11         11    0.13 #>      age:sex   RW()   age    22         22    0.33 #>  #>  disp: mean = 1 #>  #>  n_draw var_time var_age var_sexgender optimizer #>    1000     time     age           sex    nlminb #>  #>  time_total time_max time_draw iter converged                    message #>        0.38     0.21      0.15   17      TRUE   relative convergence (4) #>   ## original data, plus imputed values for outcome mod |>   augment() #> ℹ Adding variable `.divorces` with true values for `divorces`. #> # A tibble: 242 × 9 #>    age   sex     time divorces    .divorces population .observed #>    <fct> <chr>  <int>    <dbl> <rdbl<1000>>      <dbl>     <dbl> #>  1 15-19 Female  2011        0     0 (0, 1)     154460 0         #>  2 15-19 Female  2012        6     6 (5, 7)     153060 0.0000392 #>  3 15-19 Female  2013        3     3 (2, 4)     152250 0.0000197 #>  4 15-19 Female  2014        3     3 (2, 4)     152020 0.0000197 #>  5 15-19 Female  2015        3     3 (2, 4)     152970 0.0000196 #>  6 15-19 Female  2016        3     3 (2, 4)     154170 0.0000195 #>  7 15-19 Female  2017        6     6 (5, 7)     154450 0.0000388 #>  8 15-19 Female  2018        0     0 (0, 1)     154170 0         #>  9 15-19 Female  2019        3     3 (2, 4)     154760 0.0000194 #> 10 15-19 Female  2020        0     0 (0, 1)     154480 0         #> # ℹ 232 more rows #> # ℹ 2 more variables: .fitted <rdbl<1000>>, .expected <rdbl<1000>>  ## parameter estimates library(dplyr) mod |>   components() |>   filter(term == "datamod") #> # A tibble: 3 × 4 #>   term    component level               .fitted #>   <chr>   <chr>     <chr>          <rdbl<1000>> #> 1 datamod prob      Female       0.96 (0.82, 1) #> 2 datamod prob      Male         0.98 (0.86, 1) #> 3 datamod rate      rate   0.027 (0.011, 0.055)  ## the data have in fact been confidentialized, ## so we account for that, in addition ## to accounting for undercoverage and ## overcoverage mod <- mod |>  set_confidential_rr3() |>  fit() #> Building log-posterior function... #> Finding maximum... #> Drawing values for hyper-parameters... mod #>  #>     ------ Fitted Poisson model ------ #>  #>    divorces ~ age * sex + time #>  #>                  exposure: population #>                data model: miscount #>       confidentialization: rr3 #>  #>         term  prior along n_par n_par_free std_dev #>  (Intercept) NFix()     -     1          1       - #>          age   RW()   age    11         11    1.94 #>          sex NFix()     -     2          2    0.32 #>         time   RW()  time    11         11    0.13 #>      age:sex   RW()   age    22         22    0.30 #>  #>  disp: mean = 1 #>  #>  n_draw var_time var_age var_sexgender optimizer #>    1000     time     age           sex    nlminb #>  #>  time_total time_max time_draw iter converged                    message #>        0.81     0.43      0.34   17      TRUE   relative convergence (4) #>

title: Specify Noise Data Model — set_datamod_noise
text: Specify data model observed outcome = true outcome + error, error symmetric distribution mean 0. true outcome normal distribution, error normal distribution. true outcome Poisson distribution, error symmetric Skellam distribution.

title: Specify Noise Data Model — set_datamod_noise
code: set_datamod_noise(mod, sd)

title: Specify Noise Data Model — set_datamod_noise
text: mod object class "bage_mod", created mod_norm() mod_pois(). sd Standard deviation measurement errors. single number, data frame '' variables.

title: Specify Noise Data Model — set_datamod_noise
text: revised version mod.

title: Specify Noise Data Model — set_datamod_noise
text: model assumes outcome variable unbiased. fact evidence biases, evidence used create de-biased version outcome variable data, de-biased version used mod_norm() mod_pois(). set_datamod_noise() used Poisson model, dispersion term Poisson rates must set zero. can done using set_disp(), though set_datamod_noise() also .

title: Specify Noise Data Model — set_datamod_noise
text: Skellam distribution restricted integers, can take positive negative values. $$X_1 \sim \text{Poisson}(\mu_1)$$ $$X_2 \sim \text{Poisson}(\mu_2)$$ $$Y = X_1 - X_2$$ \(\text{Skellam}(\mu_1, \mu_2)\) distribution. \(\mu_1 = \mu_2\), distribution symmetric.

title: Specify Noise Data Model — set_datamod_noise
text: sd can single number, case standard deviation used cells. sd can also data frame variable called "sd" one columns '' variables. instance,  sd   implies measurement errors standard deviation 330 females 240 males.
code: data.frame(sex = c("Female", "Male"),            sd = c(330, 240))

title: Specify Noise Data Model — set_datamod_noise
text: model observed outcome $$y_i^{\text{obs}} = y_i^{\text{true}} + \epsilon_i$$ $$\epsilon_i \sim \text{N}(0, s_{g[]}^2)$$ \(y_i^{\text{true}}\) normal distribution, $$\epsilon_i \sim \text{Skellam}(0.5 s_{g[]}^2, 0.5 s_{g[]}^2)$$ \(y_i^{\text{true}}\) Poisson distribution, \(y_i^{\text{obs}}\) observed outcome cell \(\); \(y_i^{\text{true}}\) true outcome cell \(\); \(\epsilon_i\) measurement error cell \(\); \(s_{g\lbrack \rbrack }\) standard deviation measurement error cell \(\).

title: Specify Noise Data Model — set_datamod_noise
code: ## Normal model ------------------------------  ## prepare outcome variable library(dplyr, warn.conflicts = FALSE) spend <- nld_expenditure |>   mutate(log_spend = log(value + 1))  ## specify model mod <- mod_norm(log_spend ~ age * diag + year,                 data = spend,                 weights = 1) |>   set_datamod_noise(sd = 0.1)  ## fit model mod <- mod |>   fit() #> Building log-posterior function... #> Finding maximum... #> Drawing values for hyper-parameters... mod #>  #>     ------ Fitted normal model ------ #>  #>    log_spend ~ age * diag + year #>  #>                data model: noise #>  #>         term  prior along n_par n_par_free std_dev #>  (Intercept) NFix()     -     1          1       - #>          age   RW()   age    18         18    0.28 #>         diag    N()     -    18         18    0.05 #>         year   RW()  year     4          4    0.06 #>     age:diag   RW()   age   324        324    0.93 #>  #>  disp: mean = 1 #>  #>  n_draw var_time var_age optimizer #>    1000     year     age    nlminb #>  #>  time_total time_max time_draw iter converged                    message #>        0.39     0.15      0.20   20      TRUE   relative convergence (4) #>   ## create new aggregated diagnositic ## group variable library(dplyr, warn.conflicts = FALSE) spend <- spend |>   mutate(diag_ag = case_when(     diag == "Neoplasms" ~ diag,     diag == "Not allocated" ~ diag,     TRUE ~ "Other"   ))  ## assume size of measurement errors ## varies across these aggregated groups sd_diag <- data.frame(diag_ag = c("Neoplasms",                                   "Not allocated",                                   "Other"),                       sd = c(0.05, 0.2, 0.1))  ## fit model that uses diagnostic-specific ## standard deviations mod <- mod_norm(log_spend ~ age * diag + year,                 data = spend,                 weights = 1) |>   set_datamod_noise(sd = sd_diag)   ## Poisson model -----------------------------  mod <- mod_pois(deaths ~ month,                 data = usa_deaths,                 exposure = 1) |>   set_datamod_noise(sd = 200) #> → Setting dispersion to zero. (Required when using noise data model with Poisson rates model.)

code: ## 'injuries' variable in 'nzl_injuries' dataset ## has been randomly rounded to base 3 mod <- mod_pois(injuries ~ age:sex + ethnicity + year,                 data = nzl_injuries,                 exposure = popn) |>   set_confidential_rr3() |> ## rather than set_datamod_outcome_rr3   fit() #> Building log-posterior function... #> Finding maximum... #> Drawing values for hyper-parameters...

title: Specify Overcount Data Model — set_datamod_overcount
text: Specify data model outcome Poisson model, outcome subject overcount

title: Specify Overcount Data Model — set_datamod_overcount
code: set_datamod_overcount(mod, rate)

title: Specify Overcount Data Model — set_datamod_overcount
text: mod object class "bage_mod_pois", created mod_pois(). rate prior overcoverage rate. data frame variable called "mean", variable called "disp", , optionally, one '' variables.

title: Specify Overcount Data Model — set_datamod_overcount
text: revised version mod.

title: Specify Overcount Data Model — set_datamod_overcount
text: overcount data model assumes reported values outcome overstate actual values. reported values might affected double-counting, instance, might include people events target population.

title: Specify Overcount Data Model — set_datamod_overcount
text: rate argument specifies prior distribution overcoverage rate. rate data frame variable called "mean", variable called "disp", , optionally, one '' variables. instance,  rate   implies reported value outcome expected overstate true value 5% females, 3% females, greater unceratinty males females.
code: data.frame(sex = c("Female", "Male"),            mean = c(0.05, 0.03),            disp = c(0.1, 0.15))

title: Specify Overcount Data Model — set_datamod_overcount
text: model observed outcome $$y_i^{\text{obs}} = y_i^{\text{true}} + \epsilon_i$$ $$\epsilon_i \sim \text{Poisson}(\kappa_{g[]} \gamma_i w_i)$$ $$\kappa_g \sim \text{Gamma}(1/d_g, 1/(d_g m_g))$$ \(y_i^{\text{obs}}\) observed outcome cell \(\); \(y_i^{\text{true}}\) true outcome cell \(\); \(\epsilon_i\) overcount cell \(\); \(\gamma_i\) rate cell \(\); \(w_i\) exposure cell \(\); \(\kappa_{g[]}\) overcoverage rate cell \(\); \(m_g\) expected value \(\kappa_g\) (specified via rate); \(d_g\) disperson \(\kappa_g\) (specified via rate).

title: Specify Overcount Data Model — set_datamod_overcount
code: ## specify 'rate' rate <- data.frame(sex = c("Female", "Male"),                    mean = c(0.1, 0.13),                    disp = c(0.2, 0.2))  ## specify model mod <- mod_pois(divorces ~ age * sex + time,                 data = nzl_divorces,                 exposure = population) |>   set_datamod_overcount(rate) mod #>  #>     ------ Unfitted Poisson model ------ #>  #>    divorces ~ age * sex + time #>  #>                  exposure: population #>                data model: overcount #>  #>         term  prior along n_par n_par_free #>  (Intercept) NFix()     -     1          1 #>          age   RW()   age    11         11 #>          sex NFix()     -     2          2 #>         time   RW()  time    11         11 #>      age:sex   RW()   age    22         22 #>  #>  disp: mean = 1 #>  #>  n_draw var_time var_age var_sexgender #>    1000     time     age           sex #>   ## fit model mod <- mod |>   fit() #> Building log-posterior function... #> Finding maximum... #> Drawing values for hyper-parameters... mod #>  #>     ------ Fitted Poisson model ------ #>  #>    divorces ~ age * sex + time #>  #>                  exposure: population #>                data model: overcount #>  #>         term  prior along n_par n_par_free std_dev #>  (Intercept) NFix()     -     1          1       - #>          age   RW()   age    11         11    2.00 #>          sex NFix()     -     2          2    0.36 #>         time   RW()  time    11         11    0.13 #>      age:sex   RW()   age    22         22    0.33 #>  #>  disp: mean = 1 #>  #>  n_draw var_time var_age var_sexgender optimizer #>    1000     time     age           sex    nlminb #>  #>  time_total time_max time_draw iter converged                    message #>        0.33     0.17      0.14   17      TRUE   relative convergence (4) #>   ## original data, plus imputed values for outcome mod |>   augment() #> ℹ Adding variable `.divorces` with true values for `divorces`. #> # A tibble: 242 × 9 #>    age   sex     time divorces    .divorces population .observed #>    <fct> <chr>  <int>    <dbl> <rdbl<1000>>      <dbl>     <dbl> #>  1 15-19 Female  2011        0     0 (0, 0)     154460 0         #>  2 15-19 Female  2012        6     6 (4, 6)     153060 0.0000392 #>  3 15-19 Female  2013        3     3 (1, 3)     152250 0.0000197 #>  4 15-19 Female  2014        3     3 (2, 3)     152020 0.0000197 #>  5 15-19 Female  2015        3     3 (2, 3)     152970 0.0000196 #>  6 15-19 Female  2016        3     3 (2, 3)     154170 0.0000195 #>  7 15-19 Female  2017        6     6 (4, 6)     154450 0.0000388 #>  8 15-19 Female  2018        0     0 (0, 0)     154170 0         #>  9 15-19 Female  2019        3     3 (2, 3)     154760 0.0000194 #> 10 15-19 Female  2020        0     0 (0, 0)     154480 0         #> # ℹ 232 more rows #> # ℹ 2 more variables: .fitted <rdbl<1000>>, .expected <rdbl<1000>>  ## parameter estimates library(dplyr) mod |>   components() |>   filter(term == "datamod") #> # A tibble: 2 × 4 #>   term    component level              .fitted #>   <chr>   <chr>     <chr>         <rdbl<1000>> #> 1 datamod rate      Female 0.091 (0.033, 0.19) #> 2 datamod rate      Male    0.11 (0.044, 0.25)  ## the data have in fact been confidentialized, ## so we account for that, in addition ## to accounting for overcoverage mod <- mod |>  set_confidential_rr3() |>  fit() #> Building log-posterior function... #> Finding maximum... #> Drawing values for hyper-parameters... mod #>  #>     ------ Fitted Poisson model ------ #>  #>    divorces ~ age * sex + time #>  #>                  exposure: population #>                data model: overcount #>       confidentialization: rr3 #>  #>         term  prior along n_par n_par_free std_dev #>  (Intercept) NFix()     -     1          1       - #>          age   RW()   age    11         11    1.93 #>          sex NFix()     -     2          2    0.32 #>         time   RW()  time    11         11    0.13 #>      age:sex   RW()   age    22         22    0.30 #>  #>  disp: mean = 1 #>  #>  n_draw var_time var_age var_sexgender optimizer #>    1000     time     age           sex    nlminb #>  #>  time_total time_max time_draw iter converged                    message #>        0.77     0.41      0.32   19      TRUE   relative convergence (4) #>
